Reviews.Title: “Amazing location.”
Reviews.Author: mcfrog55
Reviews.Content: This is a lovely hotel in an amazing location. Breakfast was varied and plentiful; rooms were clean; staff were civil. Negatives: small rooms with little storage ; paint peeling on ceiling; awkward bathrooms. If you're a light sleeper, the 5 am muezzin call, through loudspeakers, could be a real problem. Air con was bizarre.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel with a spellbinding view!”
Reviews.Author: Englishrose6
Reviews.Content: Wow what a surprise to walk out of the hotel lobby through a pretty garden to be greeted with the awesome Blue Mosque imposing into the sky. We could never get enough of this view and all lit up at night made us quite dizzy. The hotel was spotlessly clean and all staff very efficient and welcoming. We had a downstairs standard room which was larger than upstairs and had a western bathroom although the hamman bathroom looked great. Decor appropriate and tasteful. The breakfast was excellent with a wide range of cheeses, meats and all exotic nuts, fruits and jams. Mulberry berries and rose jam on yoghurt, fantastic. It is not hip and cool but it is in an old palace, more heritage than boutique and has been restored accordingly. I would defintely stay here again as it really was rather good. We had dinner in the retaurant one night and that was not bad at all with excellent service. Overall we had a perfect stay in a atmospheric and comfy hotel right in the centre of old Istanbul.

Reviews.Title: “Ideal location and adequate facilities”
Reviews.Author: Arthur D
Reviews.Content: Ideally located next to the Blue Mosque and a short walk from Aya Sofia and Sultan's Palace, this hotel is perfectly adequate, with friendly staff and a good dining and breakfast service. The rooms are on the small side, but comfortable and equipped with unique little bath rooms with heated tiled walls and seating in the shower! Staff were friendly an helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Palatial hotel across from Blue Mosque with great breakfast”
Reviews.Author: orchidnb
Reviews.Content: The hotel is a beauty in and of itself both inside and out. The rooms are adequately sized, clean and light. Our room had a lovely balcony overlooking the Blue Mosque. The staff was friendly and helpful. We had a delicious breakfast each day in a scenic dining room. I would highly recommend this hotel because aside from all of the amenities already mentioned it has a great location.

Reviews.Title: “Very special and charming hotel with ideal location”
Reviews.Author: kalinka-tours
Reviews.Content: Looking for something very special for your stay in Istanbul, then the right choice is this hotel; Sultanahmet Palace or better Sultanahmet Sarayi to use the local name ! Elegant building in late ottoman style with charming garden by the entrance. We have stayed there a number of times during the last 10 years, and the hotel is also the most popular hotel for our clients coming to Istanbul. Perfect location just down from the Blue Mosque, quiete location and fantastic vew over Bosphorus. 3 floors, no lift, 36 rooms, among them 3 deluxe rooms with big terrasses fronting the Bosphorus, a de luxe suite with same view and two balconies. 10 rooms with soem view from their balconies. The rest odf the rooms have no balcony. Half of the rooms resently rebuilt and beautifully decorated and furnished. Many rooms have old style hamam bathrooms (!) Big terracces for outdoor serving fronting the Bosphorus view. Small charming breakfastroom/restaurant. The right choice with the right atmosphere, where you know in what city you are when you wake up in the morning, - even though the calls from the minarettes of course will help you remembering....

Reviews.Title: “Great trip to Istanbul!”
Reviews.Author: Francofile37
Reviews.Content: It was our first trip to Istanbul and we stayed at this hotel after having read a few reviews etc. We were quite pleased with our experience there. First of all they include free airport pick up which is quite nice. Our room was as expected, but with a fabulous view not expected! To the left the Balsphorous! To the right the Blue Mosque! In fact the Blue Mosque was right across the street so it was always easy to find our way home! The hotel was very well located and we walked to all the major sites. It was also convenient at night to walk to several good restaurants. The rooms were on the small side, but just fine, The bed was very comfortable. I agree with other reviews that the walls were rather thin and you could hear people talking sometimes in other rooms. The bathrooms are "Turkish" style and on the small side but we were okay with that. The staff was very friendly and helpful. The restaurant had a fabulous view over the Balsphorous and the food and variety was very good. All in all we enjoyed our stay and would stay there again no problem! If you want a pool, spa, or if you are adverse to walking up a flight or two to your room it is not the place for you..

Reviews.Title: “Love it or hate it!”
Reviews.Author: jbav48
Reviews.Content: Frommer's guide said you either love or hate this place! It is very Turkish, not at all corporate, but I found it charming. It is quietly efficient, in a marvellous position for sightseeing and the staff are delightful. There is a roof top restaurant, laptop available free in the corner of the reception area, garden at the front right opposite the Blue Mosque! Fantastic! The decor is quite 'brown' and I presume tradionally Turkish. But it is cool and clean and spacious. The bedrooms were quiet, they have a hamam style bathroom which I'm not sure I fathomed quite. But it was a very pleasant 4 nights and I would certainly return to it. I think it gives good value.

Reviews.Title: “Feel like royalty”
Reviews.Author: LazyDays4Us
Reviews.Content: Perfect location - opposite the short-cut to Blue Mosque, Mosaics museum, and markets, cafes, restaurants. 5 minutes stroll to the "cafe strip". Easy walking distance to sites. Our room overlooked the Masmar Sea, with private balcony and hamam bathroom. Firm, massive beds (great after a big day exploring..on foot!). Safe surrounds, very helpful and friendly staff. They can organise Bosporus Cruise/Tour (worth it). Breakfasts were plenty-full. Drinks on the restaurant's balcony after an exhausting day is a wonderful reward. And dinners were superb & reasonably priced on the nights we ate in. Stayed for 5 nights.....loved Istanbul, loved the Sultanahmet Palace (also known as Sultanahmet Sarayi).

Reviews.Title: “A truly palace!!”
Reviews.Author: NSTAVROS
Reviews.Content: In the heart of the old city a few steps from all the magnificent heritage of the Byzantine Empire. Very warm welcome from a smiley good looking staff. Fast check in to a superior room with a breathtaking view to Bosporus!! Rooms with private hamam!! It's a must to ask for this kind of room. Ottoman baths with spicy fragrances will carrying you to the Halima's ' 1000's nights after an exhausting shopping among the largest malls of Europe.Breakfast like sultan and dinner with live popular music will lead you to a smooth sleep. Free transfer from the airport for one way route.Luxury is all around you and Iznic plates decorates the walls.Ideal for business, families and romantic couples, Surely we will return soon.

Reviews.Title: “perfect walking distance to sites”
Reviews.Author: Mansel_11
Reviews.Content: Stayed here last November with wonderful weather and could have done with aircon. agree with what everyone else has said about size of the bathroom but plenty of hot water. Decor rather sparkly and breakfast fine but it's the location which is brilliant-opposite the entrance to the Mosaics museum which looks nothing on the outside but which is incredible and then an easy walk hrough the Stables bazaar where tourists were not harassed and some good quality goods sold there and a pleasant food area and a few minutes walk to all the major sites. Didn't eat in the reastaurant and didn't take a laptop -hotels own was very old and slow and worrying when I wanted to check in on line but reception offered to do it for me

Reviews.Title: “Great, peaceful hotel in magnificent location”
Reviews.Author: aina54
Reviews.Content: Stayed for 3 nights and the view from my bedroom was superb - Marmaris Sea on my left, Blue Mosque on the right. Have read some reviews which criticise hamman style bathrooms. I would suggest you enter into the spirit of the bathing experience, you might enjoy it. The shower is very powerful and loads of hot water - what not to like? Breakfast very good, with plenty of choice, waiters all helpful. Reception organised Bosphorous trip for me, everything went like clockwork. After a busy day sightseeing with the crowds in Istanbul, it was a pleasure to walk through the gates of the hotel, an oasis in the centre of the throng. Thanks for a great stay.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Hotel, Great Location”
Reviews.Author: DaiWeiShi
Reviews.Content: This was a very nice hotel in the heart of the Sultanamet , walking distance to all the major attractions. Very nice rooms, greta breakfast and a good, not great restaurant attached, but walking distance to several very interesting restaurants.

Reviews.Title: “Great location but avoid 'Hamam' style bathrooms”
Reviews.Author: elsemm
Reviews.Content: 1st room on top floor. Aircon not working properly. Hamam style bathroom stupid and small - avoid. Asked to move rooms and was moved to a room on the ground floor which was very nice and larger with normal western style bathroom. Breakfast poor quality with staff who did very little. Reception staff were good.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent location”
Reviews.Author: caroldh
Reviews.Content: The hotel is in an excellent spot within easy walking distance of all major sites. Room was clean and tidy. Bathroom would have been better without hammam style shower which took up too much room but was ok .Breakfast was fine without being special. Gardens and outside area for breakfast were an added bonus. On the whole, a good place for a city break.

Reviews.Title: “More Good Than Bad”
Reviews.Author: m1128
Reviews.Content: We spendt four nights at the Sultanahamet Palace after checking out of a near by hotel whose rooms were only slightly larger than my computer screen. The Sultanahamet Palace has a lot--potentially--going for it. It is a supurb location--right behind the Blue Mosque and in easy walking distance to Hagia Sophia, The Hippodorme, the Topkapki Palace, The Cistern and many other sights suchs at the Grand Bazaar. It also is very close to the Sultanahamet stop on the tram line--which is an excellent and reasonable way to get around Istanbul. For instance the last stop on the line--only about a 15 minute ride on the tram leaves you off five minutes from the Dombache Palace. The grounds around the hotel are very inviting nad most rooms have a balcony over looking the Mamara Sea. It also is near many restaurant. The hotel's resturant is very nice and has a good view of the sea, and is not expensive. The hotel includes an ample buffet breakfast with many choices. They also offer free service either from the airport or to the airport which we took advantage of for a flight leaving 6:00 a.m. Many of the service people are helpful, speak excellent English and are knowledgable. There also is free internet service available---when it is working. The rooms are clean and standard size. So what are the problems. Here goes: While most of the staff of the hotel are pleasant and all of the people in the restaurant are pleasant, a few are quite rude. For instance when we asked for help in using the TV, it was an enormous chore for the staff member who came to our room. When you ask for directions to a sight or restaurant recommendation, the standard response is to want to hook you up with one of their tours, or have some restaurant with which they have an affiliation pick you up. They are reluctant to give you directions to get there on your own. The air conditioning is really not adequate for the rooms facing west which gets intense afternoon sun. I would suggest a room facing east, but not facing the garden. While internet service is techically available, the server was down all four days we were there. It appears that this is a not an infrequent occurrence. The major limitation, however, is with the bath. Although the hotel when we were there was primarily used by Europeans and Asians,all baths have a traditional Turkish hamam which takes up about 3/4 of the shower area in a relatively small bathroom. Moreover, when the hammam fills up with water, there is no way for it to drain out until the cleaning staff empties it each morning with a wet vac. While some may consider this an interesting aspect of enjoying another culture, we found it a bit of a nuisance as well as questionable as to its sanitary aspects with water laying around for up to 12 hours or more. At 150 euros a night, I do not think some of these limitations should exist. Moreover, it is quite unfortunate because there are many nice features of the hotel. Since we did not do much more than sleep and have breakfast there, as we were out most days, the limitations did not interfere with our stay in Instanbul. However, I would be aware of what one is getting at the Sultahamet Palace.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location, Friendly Service, Good Value”
Reviews.Author: Carol000
Reviews.Content: We stayed in this hotel for our first trip to Istanbul in April 2009. Its location was absolutely excellent - right behind the Blue Mosque (yes you could hear the Muezzins call very distinctly but we felt this added to our experience) and we walked to all the major 'attractions' Topkapi, Sultanahmet Square, Hagia Sophia, local Turkish Bath Haman - and we are not keen walkers! Hotel Reception booked all trips and dealt with all requests very efficiently. Breakfast was ok - normal continental self service. We had one evening meal in the hotel (it was raining!) and were very pleasantly surprised. It was very tasty food, well presented and very reasonable. Very attractive hotel in the Turkish style which we wanted. Would most definitely stay here again for a second trip.

Reviews.Title: “Unreservedly loved this hotel”
Reviews.Author: HAGLEY
Reviews.Content: I selected the Sultanahmet Palace for a four night stay after reading about it on Frommers' online guide. I've found this a reliable source in the past and it didn't fail me on this occasion. I did question my selection in the days leading up to my stay because of some of the things I read on Trip Advisor but I'm glad I didn't reverse course but it proved to be a perfect choice. First, the hotel is in the Sultanahmet district which has immense character and is the location of several of the must-see sites such as the Blue Mosque. A lot of hotels are in or near Taksim Square, but while that is in the more "happening" area of Beyoglu it seemed too busy, too modern and too congested. I can honestly say that Istanbul would have been a totally different experience if I hadn't stayed in the Sultanahmet district. Second, the hotel has the most fantastic view of the Blue Mosque on one side and lovely views of the sea on the opposite side. The hotel serves breakfast on this seaview side and this was a lovely way to start the day. Third, the staff were uniformly gracious, helpful and pleasant and -- like so many people we met in Turkey -- had a great command of English. Fourth, the hotel has everything you might seek if you really want to experience the novelty and attraction of being in a totally different environment (the central purpose of travel, it seems to me.) It was fun to see a hammam in the bathroom, the stained glass ceiling way above the lobby, and some of the ornamental objects here and there in the public spaces. What is the point of travelling thousands of miles from the USA if your hotel looks like a boutique hotel in Chicago? The Sultanahmet Palace's old-world charm was definitely one of the key reasons we loved Istanbul. Fifth, back to the breakfast. This is a generously endowed buffet which seems at pains to meet the expectations of all the different nationalities likely to visit the hotel. I am a native Brit, so could enjoy familiar things like scrambled eggs, but there were selections that would appeal to Germans, Dutch, etc., plus lots of Mediterranean specialties like olives, yogurt and on and on. There was no need to eat again for hours! Sixth, one thing I will remember always is being woken up at five a.m. or thereabouts by the call to prayer from the Blue Mosque (heavily amplified!) More than any other city I have ever visited, Istanbul is memorable not only for it sights and smells but its sounds. For some people, this might sound like an unwelcome invasion of sleep but for us it was part of the magic of Istanbul. I hope this is helpful and informative.

Reviews.Title: “Poor value, tired property”
Reviews.Author: Garin_Zagnot
Reviews.Content: The Sultanahmet Palace is located in the heart of the tourist district of Istanbul, very close to the Blue Mosque. The location is convenient to most major site-seeing attractions. We stayed at this hotel three years ago, were pleased with the location, and satisfied enough with the hotel to try it again on our May 2008 visit to Istanbul. When we stayed previously, the rooms got unusually hot even in relatively cool weather, but the clunky central air conditioning system worked well enough to keep the room habitable. We figured that having that A/C available would work again this time. The hotel was a bit tired-looking then, and unfortunately nothing has been done to update the property in the mean time. It is not in poor repair, just very tired. Senior or disabled travelers should be aware that the hotel has no elevator. The Sultanahmet Palace unsuccessfully attempts to give an authentic feel by providing hamam-style bathrooms. This is a bit quaint at first, but quickly becomes annoying. For 200 Euros, we had a deluxe room with a view of the Blue Mosque. While this sounds terrific, it proved problematic. Once in the room, we learned that the air conditioning system had not been turned on yet, and the A/C blew hot air (it only gives heat or cool to the entire hotel, nothing in between, and no individual controls). We were told by management that we should "just open the window" and that would take care of it. The problem is that with a room facing a street carrying a constant stream of traffic--primarily tour buses--one became overwhelmed with the noise and fumes. The window had to stay closed until night. At night, a large number of feral cats screeched and fought all night long on the hotel grounds. It was impossible to sleep for more than a few minutes at a time. We checked out after the first night to go to Ephesus for the weekend, with a reservation to return to the Sultanahmet Palace when we came back to Istanbul. Management swore to me--and I asked and received the same answer three times--that the air conditioning would be on when we returned. I requested that our reservation be changed to a Standard room, to which they agreed, for a rate of 145 Euros. We had no interest in dealing with the street noise again, and the cats had seemed to focus their partying in the front courtyard of the hotel. Upon our return, we found the air conditioning still not functioning. Management's response was that it was "cold" and unnecessary. The room was brutally hot in spite of seasonally normal outdoor temperatures. I reminded them of their promise, and received the response that I should just open the window, and everything would be fine. For the record, even opening the window in a Standard room does little to make the room a comfortable temperature. As it was late, we stayed the night, but a brief walk around the neighborhood found many hotels that were both nicer and much less expensive. I made arrangements to move to a different hotel the next day. Management was surprised when we checked out three days early, and continued to suggest that the lack of air conditioning was not a problem in spite of their prominent advertising of it as a feature of the hotel. As I was getting this lecture again ("it's cold"; "we had a complaint about it being too cold"), another frustrated guest came to the front desk and asked for someone to come show him how to turn on the air conditioning. First lesson learned, do your research ahead of time: there are many nice, newer hotels in the Sultanahmet district at a fraction of this cost. The other hotels I looked at when looking for another hotel all had larger, more comfortable rooms. Many are in more vibrant sections of the neighborhood (this hotel is a bit isolated). All were a fraction of the cost. The Sultanahmet Palace is a very poor value. Second lesson learned, if you care about air conditioning, make sure any hotel you reserve has individually-controlled units. This shouldn't have been an issue in May, but for some reason, this particular hotel gets very warm inside even in normal spring weather. The Sultanahmet Palace is not a bad hotel, just one in need of a significant refurbishment and systems updating. The staff are pleasant but not helpful. I would strongly recommend other local options over this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, Great View”
Reviews.Author: Heironymous
Reviews.Content: Note - my wife and I got a great deal online for one of the suites during off season (New Years day). Excellent location, fabulous view (We were looking at the Blue Mosque out our window), room size - middlish considering it was a suite. Breakfast buffet was fabulous. Never ate any other meal there. (turkish food is great). I got exactly what I was looking for. A boutique hotel in a wildly interesting town.

Reviews.Title: “Quite possibly no better hotel in the Sultanahmet district”
Reviews.Author: ponca
Reviews.Content: This fine hotel is absoutly one of the most charming boutique hotels in all of Istanbul. All of the furnishings and bed clothes were in excellent and updated condition contrary to previous reviews. I found the cleanliness and upkeep exceeded standards in smilar properties in Europe and America. I stayed for four nights in room 202, It was quite a bit larger than the rooms in the center section of the hotel, very spacious and comfortable for 2 adults and 2 children and it was not even one of the Delux rooms which are much larger. The hammam shower was very nice with all the floors, walls, sink and counter of marble. Not one time did I have a problem with the flooded bathroom as other travelers have reported as there is a drain channel, as with authentic hammams, that carries the water away before it travels to the other section of the bathroom. As for the breakfast it has all of the continental trimmings with a wonderful selection of Turkish yogurts and dozens of fruit syrups and nuts that are traditionally added to it. Complimentary transportation in the hotels own Mercedes Van from the airport is a plus as one of the hotel staff meets you as you clear customs and helps you with your luggage to the van. The return trip to the airport is 35USD which is only a couple of USD more than a regular cab, a good deal. The views from the hotel are fabulous and all of the sights are only a short walk away. For 165USD a night it simply can not be beat! Book as far in advance as possible because as wonderful as this hotel is they fill up quickly. If you are lucky enough to find a delux room available book it, if not you will be satisfied with a regular room.

Reviews.Title: “Cheap and Cheerful”
Reviews.Author: joseph thornberry
Reviews.Content: Always difficult to find a simple, cheap, nice hotel in Istanbul and I have been there many times. I found this one by accident just about 100 yards up from the Cistern as you follow the tram lines. Right opposite the Blue Mosque. It is very clean and used mainly by Turks from what I could see, which is a good sign as they are usually so fussy. There was a terrace from which one could see over the Bosphorus when having quite a good buffet breakfast. I thought that because it was on the main tramline it would be noisey but it has double glazing so I heard practically nothing. I never heard the Mosques either which usually wake me up so I was happy. You have no where to walk really as you are in the centre of everything and with the tram outside your door you can go everywhere quickly. The staff (of one!) were very helpful to us as my friend broke his foot and he advised us where to go. He even gave us an old crutch for free! The price was reasonable - 25 euros for a double room. You won't do much dancing in them of course but they are very quiet - never heard a word from the other guests. Well worth using if you don't want to spend much time IN a hotel but can't spend too much money either. A real bargain.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent location but some glitches”
Reviews.Author: suzie330
Reviews.Content: You come to this hotel for the location and pleasant gardens where you can relax after sightseeing and shopping until you drop! We also found the bathrooms ridiculously small and in general the hotel rooms are poorly soundproofed. The restaurant offers very well presented and good value dinners. Much better than breakfast! The deluxe rooms are worth the extra especially if you have negotiated a reasonable rate.....like most places in Turkey this hotel offers a significant discount for cash payment.

Reviews.Title: “Resting on its laurels”
Reviews.Author: CapitalTraveler
Reviews.Content: As with other reviewers, I got the sense the Sultanahmet Palace is resting on its laurels. Because of a great write-up in Frommer's and other guide books, I got the feeling the proprieters have decided they don't need to do any updating of their look. First the pluses: As noted by all, the location is spectacular, and the common rooms are lovely. Service also quite good, although we definitely had better elsewhere in Turkey. A satisfactory stay, all in all. The minuses: The whole place is in need of an update. Bedding and furniture are 1970s-era, and everything had a bit of a threadbare, faded feel to it. Very disappointing, given the price and the competition by all sorts of botique hotels in the area. Unlike others, I found the breakfast buffet disappointing as well, especially compared to other hotels we stayed at in Turkey. I do echo the issues with the bathrooms, which start out interesting and quirky and quickly become annoying, and the strange loud noises from other parts of the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Location, good breakfast but that is all...”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Small Rooms on the 2nd floor. Tiny turkish bathroom, more of a gimmick, difficult to turn around in the tiny bathroom. The air-con did not work well in my room. In the morning, awoken by banging of doors in the other rooms. The doors do not have the automatic closing mechanism so one has to bang the door to close it. Can hear everyone outside your room. That said, the location is fabulous and the breakfast is good.

Reviews.Title: “Like a sultan”
Reviews.Author: PerUrdahl
Reviews.Content: Excellent. Next door neighbour to The Blue Mosque and easy walking to allthe great sights in Sultanahmet area. Great atmosphere. Some rooms look direct to The Blue Mosque, some direct on to the Bosporous. We preferred very much the last with a beautiful balcony. The rooms are all different and luxury. You live like the sultan did with (if you like and imagine) a touch of harem feeling. The bathrooms is very special made up as a hamman. Exotic in the start but for a longer stay than four nights we would prefer an ordinary shower. Very nice breakfast buffet. Friendly and helpful staff.
